abstract: Is this the beginning of the end of an independent Dow Jones & Company?
lead_paragraph: Is this the beginning of the end of an independent Dow Jones & Company?

headline.main: Bancrofts Agree to Meet with Murdoch

abstract: The decision represents an about-face for both the company and Rupert Murdoch’s bid and could end more than a century of family ownership.
snippet: The decision represents an about-face for both the company and Rupert Murdoch’s bid and could end more than a century of family ownership.
lead_paragraph: The family that controls Dow Jones & Company, publisher of The Wall Street Journal, announced yesterday that it would consider selling the company, ending more than a century of family ownership.

headline.main: Dow Jones Says It Will Consider Options for Sale
headline.print_headline: DOW JONES SAYS IT WILL CONSIDER OPTIONS FOR SALE

byline.original: By ANDREW ROSS SORKIN and RICHARD PÉREZ-PEÑA

abstract: Following is the preliminary statement issued Thursday evening by the Bancroft family, which controls Dow Jones & Company:As we have been since 1902, the Bancroft family remains resolute in its commitment to preserve and protect the editorial independence and integrity of The Wall Street Journal as well as the leadership, strength and vitality of The Journal and all of the other publications and services of Dow Jones.
snippet: Following is the preliminary statement issued Thursday evening by the Bancroft family, which controls Dow Jones & Company:As we have been since 1902, the Bancroft family remains resolute in its commitment to preserve and protect the editorial inde...
lead_paragraph: Following is the preliminary statement issued Thursday evening by the Bancroft family, which controls Dow Jones & Company:

abstract: The family that controls the Dow Jones & Company released a statement saying that they would meet with the News Corporation to discuss its $5 billion bid.
snippet: The family that controls the Dow Jones & Company released a statement saying that they would meet with the News Corporation to discuss its $5 billion bid.
lead_paragraph: The Bancroft family, which controls Dow Jones & Company, the owner of The Wall Street Journal, agreed late today to meet with the News Corporation to discuss its $5 billion bid.

headline.main: Bancroft Family Agrees to Meet With Murdoch

abstract: While the Bancroft family’s announcement Thursday that it would consider selling Dow Jones & Company represents a remarkable about-face for both the company and Rupert Murdoch’s $5 billion bid, it does not necessarily mean that Mr. Murdoch will capture Dow Jones, which he has long coveted.
lead_paragraph: While the Bancroft family’s announcement Thursday that it would consider selling Dow Jones & Company represents a remarkable about-face for both the company and Rupert Murdoch’s $5 billion bid, it does not necessarily mean that Mr. Murdoch will capture Dow Jones, which he has long coveted.

headline.main: Dow Jones Opens Door to Rival Bidders

abstract: Dow Jones & Company‘s stock is off and running.
lead_paragraph: Dow Jones & Company‘s stock is off and running.

headline.main: Dow Jones Shares Surge on Bancroft News

abstract: The Bancroft family may be warming to the idea of a sale, but it is still far from certain that Rupert Murdoch’s News Corporation, or any other buyer, will succeed in acquiring Dow Jones. Even less clear, Norman Pearlstine of Carlyle Group said in an interview with Bloomberg News, is what would become of Ottaway Newspapers, the nationwide chain of community papers that Dow Jones has owned since 1970.
lead_paragraph: The Bancroft family may be warming to the idea of a sale, but it is still far from certain that Rupert Murdoch’s News Corporation, or any other buyer, will succeed in acquiring Dow Jones. Even less clear, Norman Pearlstine of Carlyle Group said in an interview with Bloomberg News, is what would become of Ottaway Newspapers, the nationwide chain of community papers that Dow Jones has owned since 1970.

headline.main: Weekend Video: Pearlstine on Dow Jones

abstract: You might be tempted to agree with Dow Chemical chief executive Andrew Liveris that the story of two fired executives at his company becoming a “soap opera” — except even soap operas aren’t this confusing.
lead_paragraph: You might be tempted to agree with Dow Chemical chief executive Andrew Liveris that the story of two fired executives at his company becoming a “soap opera” — except even soap operas aren’t this confusing.

headline.main: More Weekend Video: Dows of Our Lives
